comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Imagine being a flying fox in earlier 20th century Sydney! You'd come back to town one night after spending the winter up north touring banana farms and orchards...you're following a flight path that's been etched into your DNA...as you approach the city you've got your flaps down, you're lined up to land in your favourite fig tree in Hyde Park, just like last time and the time before that...everything's going to plan, you're more or less on auto-pilot, dreaming about your next meal...when all of a sudden, out of the darkness, there's a gigantic crane looming up ahead...you flap your wings like crazy and at the last instant swerve to the left...but in so doing you suffer a critical altitude loss...now you're in dire peril of  snagging on a network of recently erected overhead wires!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Ha! I thought you had gone 'batty' from looking at these old photos. The poles and wires are really ugly - I think the were building the Cahill Expressway. GoogleMapsStreetView - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Sydney+NSW&hl=en&ll=-33...

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
Well that large building in the background is half built.   Its the museum of contemporary art  which was originally the Maritime Services Board.  If I recall correctly,  it was built around 1938,   and unlike the Opera House it didn't take 17 years to complete,   so being in a half-built condition like that should narrow down the date that the photograph was taken within about 6 months or so.
Not sure why you would have "dated earlier than 10/12/1952"  so specifically,  but I think this photo was taken about 1938 or thereabouts.

comment.author: 69195796@N05
comment._content: The tram shown in the photo doesn't appear to be a toastrack but another type (name unknown) that was in use in Sydney. The toastrack had compartments which could be entered from each side of the tram with two seats going right across the width of the vehicle. Thus each compartment lined up alongside each other and gave the impression of a toast rack with its slices of toast.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69195796@N05] You can only really see one side of the trams in this image. However, I'd assume there'd be identical openings on the opposite sides allowing entry from either side of the tram. Have a look at this image of a Toastrack 'O' class tram - there are some similarities to the trams shown in this image. www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=208027&... However we might need an expert in the tram field to confirm exactly what kind of tram it is!

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: My guess would be c. 1950 based on the date of the Government Printing Office Photography and the stage of MSB construction shown here

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I didn't realise that building was built in two halves.

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: A nice collection from the NSW Government Printer Construction of Maritime Services Board building

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Sorry I missed this one - definitely O-class tramcars. I have annotated the photo accordingly.

comment.author: 79583367@N02
comment._content: I think all three trams are "O" class.  There appear to be two tracks at left, but only one wire !!!!
